conclusion: To determine the mechanical energy loss during the collision between block C and block B, consider the forces acting on each block and the conservation of energy principle.
The skateboard A is initially at rest.
Block B is at rest on the spring.
Block C is moving with an initial velocity v0.
The collision between C and B is perfectly inelastic.
The collision time is extremely short, so the velocities of C and B after the collision can be considered as the final velocities.
The total kinetic energy of the system before the collision is KE_initial.
The total kinetic energy of the system after the collision is KE_final.
The total mechanical energy of the system is conserved.
The initial mechanical energy is equal to the final mechanical energy.
The kinetic energy of block C before the collision is (1/2)mv0^2.
The kinetic energy of block B before the collision is (1/2)kx0^2, where x0 is the initial displacement of block B on the spring.
The kinetic energy loss during the collision is Î”KE = KE_initial - KE_final.
The force exerted by the spring on block B is F = kx0, where x0 is the initial displacement of block B on the spring.
The force exerted by the spring on block C is F = -kx0, where x0 is the initial displacement of block C on the spring.
The force exerted by the spring on block B is equal to the force exerted by the spring on block C.
